bioghist.p: The Philadelphia Society for Alleviating the Miseries of Public Prisons was established in May 1787 with the goal of improving the conditions of the Walnut Street Prison. In its earlier days, the society gave relief to prisoners in the form of money and clothing, donated bibles, and visited prisoners. By the 1820s, the society focused on changing the overarching policy of the prison from group confinement to the Pennsylvania System of solitary confinement and the new Eastern State Penitentiary. The members also visited county prisons across and the state and sought just penal legislation. The society continued to grow in numbers and, as the society entered the twentieth century, it became involved in numerous studies hoping to gain a better understanding of the causes of criminality and the most effective and just paths to punishment and reformation.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Philadelphia Society for Alleviating the Miseries of Public Prisons. Materials include: reports from the society's agents to the Committee on County Prison (1862-1883), reports from the Visiting Committee to the Society, and reports to the Committee on Discharged Prisoners; minutes of the Committee on County Prison, 1856-1864; a manuscript by James J. Barclay relating to prison discipline, circa 1828; a scrapbook of newspaper clippings on prison discipline, 1843-1845; a 1787 memorial to the Pennsylvania State and House of Representatives requesting an act of incorporation; and an an account book of the Journal of Prison Discipline. The reports include case descriptions, summaries of visit made to prisoners (broken down by offense), and information about prisoners discharged from the prisons.
